comments.commentBody: Trump, Giuliani and Gingrich -- nine wives/families. between them.  So many family/Republican values between them.

If Clinton wins tomorrow, the Republican Party as we know it will be destroyed, a thing of the past. That would be great.

On the other hand, if Trump wins tomorrow, it is also the case that the Republican Party as we know it will be destroyed, a thing of the past.

Tell me again why I should be so worried about this election?

Oh right, there's a risk that also the Democratic Party as we know it will be destroyed, and the mainstream media with it.

Any chance we could get it to take out Adam Sandler movies and Zika and pumpkin spice in everything while we're at it?

replies.commentBody: Do the research. And do the math --- Then ask, what exactly is Trump going to replace it with??? and a) How long it will take?, b) How much (more) will it cost? and c) Will it offer the same coverage for those with pre-exisitng medical conditions.....That's a start.
This is a fabrication. Subsidies make the increases modest for most by any measure.

...Obamacare premiums rising at the level originally predicted by the CBO

...Obamacare breaks when it has to become GOPamacare -- if it weren't for the unwillingness of the GOP to take any constructive part in getting all Americans healthcare, we'd have a stronger system and much higher participation. So, when you start pointing fingers start by pointing at the members of your own beloved party who were more interested in scoring political points than in making good healthcare policy

comments.commentBody: Obamacare premiums going through the roof; Clinton keep Obamacare; Trump repeal & replace Obamacare - Obamacare anyone?

replies.commentBody:
Trump ripped off someone I personally met. You do not know the real actual man.
I do!

Do not tell me again The New York Times Ellen.

Hillary while not at all a rock star.. does BLOW the Orange conman away in so many aspects.

Hillary Clinton has contributed a lot of sweat equity in the cause of social justice and good of Country.  Her high unfavorables is the result of years of  outright political warfare by the Republican Party and right-wing organizations.  Her favorability raftings will increase with her presidency.

comments.commentBody:
Once again, the New York Times chooses to slice and dice the electorate while avoiding the issue - income inequality and less-than-equal opportunity, thus setting us against each other. Why can't our "land of opportunity" provide health care for all, some sort of decent social safety net, help with college tuition for deserving students, and bridges that aren't crumbling? Why did we end up with two hugely unpopular candidates, neither of whom holds out any real promise to address these pressing ills?
There is a reason for the rage, and for the fear, and if they are not addressed now, which it looks as if they will not be, they will certainly not go away no matter which candidate wins.
Anyone who has a college degree and still plans to vote for Donald Trump needs a major refund on that "education" they received.

Watching the rally in Philadelphia, I am just so hard pressed to fathom why anyone would support the vitriol of Donald Trump. I mean, if it were really just about policies, I could understand ...but it's not. It's about an attitude of resentment, blame, anger, and superiority vs acceptance, responsibility, fairness, and inclusion.

Hey every citizen gets one vote. Time to wrap this up and let the people speak.

replies.commentBody: From Kentucky, the horse state which elected a governor who ran on depriving people of health care. What a place! Trump country, naturally.

comments.commentBody: In 24 hours the election day results will be out. Polls are useless. So far polls have declared HRC the next president of the USA. Tomorrow the American people will tell us who they want as their next president. I have no doubt that Hillary will win the popular vote but I am uncertain about who will win the electoral college. This will be my fifth presidential election and probably the most important of my life. I would not be surprised if HRC wins but if Trump wins it will be an earth quake that will shake the world and will register a 10 on the Richter scale of world events.

replies.commentBody:
And what that should tell you is how corrupt the system is that allows the Clintons free reign to lie cheat and steal. If you really don't recognize the corruption here then I fear you are far too blinded by partisan politics.
Hillary lies, Bill steals and Obama declines to prosecute and you applaud! Nice.
By measurements,Trump lies about 3X as much as Clinton. Funny how his lies are ignored by his supporters.

Steve W from the Far Right,

Ah, if only you and the people you hang with could find the time to bring facts with your bizarre claims and conspiracy theories the rest of us would stop dismissing you as having nothing meaningful to say...

comments.commentBody: Of course we all know what the election would look like if the media was not so in the tank for the Dems. Landslide Trump victory. This election, in particular the media have been blatantly vitriolic against Republicans in general and Mr Trump in particular. Pretty amazing that the Doug Band Teneo memo showing the huge sums that he arranged to be paid to "Clinton Inc" as well as the corruption at the heart of CGI has just passed like a mist through the reportage of the NY Times and the rest of the media. Appears corruption on the left is just the price of admission and no big deal to the press!

Not sure how the NY Times could know with such seeming certainty who the ballots already cast are for. They must be assuming that D or R registered voters will stay 100% in the fold. In an election like this that might not be true!

Going to be very interesting to see what actually happens but seems like there is some wishful thinking embedded in this polls assumptions.

North Carolina on my mind, remembering the first friend I made in New York when returning at 19. Eileen was her name. My neighbor, she gave me such a warm welcome that I was mistrustful. Mistrusful that Americans could be so open-hearted to one another.

She was 28 at the time, vivacious, bright and so kind. On occasion, she would tell me of growing up in her Home State and how she caused a disturbance as a teen when inviting Martin Luther King to address her all-White School, her uncle was a member of the 'Cukoo' Clan, as I will always call the Ku-Klux-Klan, abolished by Congress in 1871.

As I write, there is a picture she left me of the Virgin Mary astride a donkey and Joseph leading the way in their flight to freedom. She must have chosen this last gift for a reason, and I know that we both would have wept together years later if 'White Supremacy', supported by Trump, had still not gone with the wind.

The most disturbing and outrageous factor of the past two years of constant polling and opining has been the total vacuum the media has been able to impose on anything resembling journalism. There is not a dearth of factual reporting, there is none. There are polls aplenty to support the horserace of speculation and just as many "reperters" to keep them growing.
What there is not is factual presentation. As a result we are voting for two of the least liked, least suitable candidates to lead the country in many decades and virtually ignorant of the serious problesm we should be confronting regarding health care, education, global warming, pestilential growth of military bases, and an electoral process undermined by corruption, ignorance, and fearfulness.
Its baked in for Hillary!

replies.commentBody: Huh.  So let's analyze what you just said. First, you "don't know a single person who is voting R. Then you go on to say " the majority of the people I know who are voting R are only focused on one or two issues...". So the majority of nobody are focused on one or two issues... Now who can argue with that kind of logic? I think I can see the the big picture now.

comments.commentBody: As someone who lives and works in the Triangle, I don't know a single person who is voting R. However, Durham and Orange counties are incredibly liberal and voted >70% for Obama in 2008 and 2012. You indeed do have a lot of transplants (I moved down here from the NE), but it more comes down that we can analyze who to vote by looking at the overall picture. A majority of people I know who are voting R are only focused on one or two issues (abortion and/or guns) and refuse to look at the big picture.

replies.commentBody: Or it's a white man pretending to be black, as if his lone comment will sway the black voters. Who knew black people were threatened by Latinos?

@anonymous
Hard to believe any White man would want to "pretend to be Black"...but it did sound that way, didn't it?

These two replies (from NYC) demonstrate the elite's disconnect from the poor, a disconnect Trump's campaign recognizes and preys upon. When people are struggling, they'll blame their problems on anyone but themselves; this is how Hitler became so popular. There is absolutely a tension and distrust among black and Latino people in many neighborhoods, including the one I got out of. Poor black people have to compete with equally poor, newly-arrived Latinos for housing, benefits, and (less frequently) jobs. This competition, combined with the colorism that still characterizes these neighborhoods, leads many poor black people to perceive lighter-skinned Latinos as "uppity" and opportunist. I have no doubt that many black people sympathize with Trump's demonizing of Latinos, nor do I doubt that this commenter is a black man.

comments.commentBody: I'm black and will be voting Trump. I just pray he wins or all we'll be hearing for the rest of our lives is "Latino this, Latino that". It's too much there are other people in this country.

Tell all you see and know to vote ONLY Democrat 2016 and shove the Republican'ts and deplorables including those unAmerican unpatriotic "people" in NC, so far down that they will never recover and end up in the trash heap of history where they belong.

I am trying to imagine a place where Trump and Clinton are tied, what their values might be like.

New York City needs a leader that values diversity. That much is true. Maybe diversity is not values in other places?

Puerto Rico is diverse in its own way but one thing we have in common, we are all Puerto Rican

I don't think Trump's values are as universal as his party claims. His campaign has revolved around attacking his rival, showing how much "momentum" he has, but not really demonstrating the viability of his own project. His gimmicks like the wall etc are getting pretty tired.

Look not everyone feels they benefitted from the Obama administration. I am from Puerto Rico and constantly surprised at our (not really me but everybody else's) skepticism of Obama policy towards us. We feel the economic growth of the mainland has left us behind. Crippling debt is choking our economy with no avail.

A lot of the Puerto Rican populist rhetoric leans towards Trump, the very person planning to revoke our citizenship. Those of us on the mainland get to vote, those who live here do not.

replies.commentBody:
Dave I do hope that you are correct.
Dave

comments.commentBody: In 30 hours the Billionaire Bozo will be the most hated man in the History of the Republican Party. He is TOAST.

replies.commentBody:
As long as you equate people to polls you are missing the point.
Not only that, there are a lot more voters out there who for one reason or the other, haven't been polled.

The poll doesn't separate out gender, so we do't know whether there is a gender difference. However, in every major national poll the has been a dramatic difference between how white men and women are voting.

The poll shows that 50% of college-educated folk are for Trump and 41% for Clinton. It is whites with no degree who are at 67%.

There's no mention of College-educated Blacks, and Blacks without a degree.
Bit of an oversight, don't you think???

comments.commentBody:
People refer to Trump's base as being uneducated, white males. But this poll shows that whites in North Carolina - of all educations and genders - are voting Trump 2:1 over Clinton.

The poll only seems to recognize whites and blacks: what's going on with the 8.3% that are neither white nor black? Because if the white/black vote is essentially a tie, then I'd posit the other 8.3% are minorities who lean towards Clinton.

replies.commentBody: More like suicide-prevention.

comments.commentBody: In other words, North Carolina appears to be up for grabs even though a whole batch of polls shows Clinton with the same lead, which makes the margin of error look a whole lot smaller.  But we wouldn't want to say that because we need the horse race to keep people interested.

replies.commentBody:
Perhaps, just perhaps -- more Whites without a degree are prone to vote for Trump because a) He's skewing his meessage toward them and b) those with a colege education may tend to be more intellectually circumspect in thier choices.
Another thing.
It's probably safe to say that both non-College, and College-educated Blacks would probably not go for Trump because of his vehemently bigoted rhetoric, which has nothing to do with any influence from the President and First Lady.

Why in this day and age do we have Americans without a college degree? For many jobs going today, a Masters degree is a requirement. This country needs to address the cost if higher education. Short of that, jobs will go overseas where young people are now more educated.  It is all about education, stupid?

@wgikonyo
Take caution. Or you might be pegged for sounding like an elite.
Besides, in some vocations it's possible to gain employment without holding a Master's degree -- experience also counts.
But it's true, the cost of higher education should be addressed.
And no offense, but it's not very polite to call others stupid -- it doesn't make your point any more valid.

comments.commentBody:
Mr. Cohn needs to address the following:

A category or two missing from his analysis: "College-educated minorities" and "Minorities without degrees"

Is this just another example of a Sovietized press in Hillary's corner?

NYT page-one headline: "Donald Trump’s Big Bet on Less Educated Whites"
The unwritten real story and stats: Hillary--with Barack's and Michelle's help--has made a "huge" bet on "less educated" minorities in large metropolitan areas of the nation, particularly black populations in the inner-cities, and that seems to be paying off.

Why not for Trump, too?

Is this--"Whites without a degree"--somehow a "deplorable" vote for Trump, whereas for Hillary "minorities without a degree" is just part of the DNC Politburo expectation and given every four years?

Standing back from this, it's all too easy state that these non-college-educated whites are a product of their own making. But really, where the failure lies is in the US government's lack of leadership, when we were faced with increased global competition. We missed an opportunity to help the middle class in a big way. Now we have angry voters who want a "wrecking ball".
I have been hoping college educated woman Republicans would vote for Clinton. My heart will break if NC goes red again. Everyone I know except two people have already voted for Clinton.
Perfect recipe for trouble. Serious trouble.

I've read about North Carolina's Republican Party disenfranchising minority voters through tricks and blatantly illegal acts. Can they be tried for breaking laws? Can the North Carolina vote count be delayed in a 50-50 tie for the disenfranchised voters to get their say?

Everyone should have a right to vote their mind, and no party should be able to limit this expression of choice.
With that poll, if Trump is tied, he's ahead. And in early balloting, he's way out performing Romney in Fla., NC and Colo. May be an interesting election day tomorrow.
